intro: Gossypium dicladum, commonly known as the two-branched cotton, is a species of flowering plant in the mallow family. It is native to the arid and semi-arid regions of North America, particularly in the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and small, palmate leaves. Its flowers are typically pink or purple and are followed by fluffy, cotton-like burs that contain the seeds. Gossypium dicladum is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments and is often found in rocky soils.
